items.hed: A Guide to Mexico City's Architectural Moment
How to Do Paris Fashion Week Like A Street Style Star
How Travel Inspired Michael Kors's New Shoe Collection
How to Pack for a Week in Paris
Where New York’s Most Fashionable People Shop
Mexico City's Architectural Moment: A Guide
items.dek: Long an export, Mexico's finest architects have started staying home — and the work they're doing there isn't just some of the finest in Mexico, it's some of the finest in the world. Here's a short list of the buildings you absolutely must see.

items.title: CENTRO
items.caption: Mexico City is having a major architectural moment. The country is producing many fine architects who, rather than leaving Mexico to pursue careers, are staying home and helping change the face of their capital city. One of those architects is Enrique Norten, whose bold, graphic redesign of CENTRO, a university for creative studies, covers some 55,000 square feet. It was done in partnership with Dutch-born, Mexico-based architect Jan Hendrix and features LEED-certified buildings and a public park. The campus reopens in September 2015.

items.title: Luis Barragán House
items.caption: The late Pritzker Prize-winning architect Luis Barragán, born in Guadalajara, designed homes, churches, and other buildings throughout Mexico. His [home and studio](http://www.casaluisbarragan.org/) in Mexico City, on the southern edge of Chapultepec Park, is a UNESCO Heritage Site. Up close you can see Barragán's angular, brightly color-blocked work.

items.title: Museo Soumaya
items.caption: [Museo Soumaya](http://www.museosoumaya.com.mx/index.php/eng/), designed by Mexican architect Fernando Romero and funded by Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim (Soumaya was the name of his late wife), is an eruptive, undulating pair of buildings in the posh Polanco neighborhood. The silver structure pictured here is known as the Plaza Corso. It houses the modern section of the Museo Soumaya's extensive art collection. When it opened in 2011, it created a huge splash and is now the most-visited art museum in the entire country.

items.title: Camino Real Hotel
items.caption: The [Camino Real](http://www.caminoreal.com/destinations/polanco-en), which is also located in Polanco, bills itself as a "Hotel-Museum." Designed by Mexico City native Ricardo Legorreta in 1968, the Teōtīhuacān-style pyramid shares space with bright pink and yellow geometric patterns. It was made as an homage to both modern and ancient Mexico.

items.title: Museo Jumex
items.caption: Down the road from the Museo Soumaya, is [Museo Jumex](http://fundacionjumex.org/en/site/museojumex), which reportedly has the largest private collection of contemporary art in Mexico. The jagged-topped museum was funded by Carlos Slim and designed by a British-based architecture firm, headed by David Chipperfield.

items.title: Arcos Bosques
items.caption: Arcos Bosques, or "Forest Arches," is an office and high-end mall complex in the D.F.'s Santa Fe business district. Designed by Mexican architect Teodoro González de León, the interconnected buildings are 36 stories tall on each side (making it the sixth tallest building in the city) and boast a rooftop helipad for VIP guests. Around town, Arcos Bosques is often called "El Pantalon," or "The Pants," because of its shape.

items.title: Calakmul Building
items.caption: The Calakmul Building, usually called "La Lavandera" or "The Washing Machine,” is also located in Santa Fe. Mexican architect Agustín Hernández Navarro named the building after an ancient Mayan city, even though the concept is thoroughly modern. For a long time, Santa Fe was a falling-apart neighborhood on the edge of the city, but gentrification and an influx of industry has made it a haven for new, creative architecture and design.

items.seoTitle: Museo Jumex, Luis Barragan House: A Guide to Mexico City's Best Modern Architecture
items.seoDescription: Long an export, Mexico's finest architects have started staying home — and the work they're doing there isn't just some of the finest in Mexico, it's some of the finest in the world. Here's a short list of the buildings you absolutely must see.
items.socialTitle: 7 Buildings You Must See On Your Next Trip to Mexico City
items.socialDescription: Long an export, Mexico's finest architects have started staying home — and the work they're doing there isn't just some of the finest in Mexico, it's some of the finest in the world. Here's a short list of the buildings you absolutely must see.

fields.name: Lilit Marcus
fields.shortBio: Lilit Marcus is *Condé Nast Traveler*'s contributing digital editor.
fields.bio: Lilit Marcus is a Brooklyn-based journalist and *Condé Nast Traveler*'s contributing digital editor. Her first book, *Save the Assistants: A Guide for Surviving and Thriving in the Workplace,* was published by Hyperion. Lilit's favorite destinations include Lisbon, Tel Aviv, Nashville, and Mexico City. Her work has also appeared in The Wall Street Journal, Glamour, The Guardian, Cosmopolitan, and The New York Observer.

items.hed: How to Do Paris Fashion Week Like A Street-Style Star
items.dek: Creative director and *Condé Nast Traveler* contributing editor Sofia Sanchez de Betak gives us her must list for Paris Fashion Week.
items.body:
[#image: /photos/55a035c57772ff921f95d428]||||||





Since she splits her time between New York and Paris, and attends shows in both cities (not to mention Milan and London) during fashion month, we asked street style star Sofia Sanchez de Betak to let us know where she goes to eat, shop, primp, and more in the City of Light.

##Where to Prep:
"I've been getting facials by Jean Pierre at [Jean Pierre Esthetique](http://www.sothys.fr/en/point-of-sale/jean-pierre-esthetique) since I was a little girl, and my grandmother used to visit him every week when we came to Paris. For hair I go to [Stephane Pous](http://www.stephanepous.com/salon.php)—he's the best colorist in Paris. I love his charming little salon, which is hidden in the 11th arrondisement. And Lucienne Malatesta is the best tailor I know. She works for some of the biggest couture houses during fashion week, and the rest of the year she helps me get my closet in shape!"

##Where to Shop:

"It may sound obvious, but 


[#shop: /shops/558b0e1a3a5d79a77fcd0269]||||||





 is still the ultimate fashion destination in Paris. They always manage to be on the edge and carry the best designers. I also love [Repossi](http://www.repossi.com/), and what [artistic director] Gaia Repossi has done to the brand. Her pieces are modern and at the same time classic. [The Marché aux Puces](http://www.marcheauxpuces-saintouen.com/1.aspx) is a pleasure to walk around. It feels separate from Paris, like you're in a tiny town with charming streets. And [Galerie 213](http://www.galerie213.com/) is the best place to find the most fascinating books in the city. It's by appointment only, and they specialize in collector's-edition photography books. Plus if you ask for them (insistently), they also have a great collection of rare vinyl records!"


[#image: /photos/55b6a2ff0121edec25708439]||||||








##Where to Eat:
 
"The classic [Caviar Kaspia](http://www.caviarkaspia.com/fr/) is a must during Paris Fashion Week, either for a private fashion dinner in the back room, or a romantic caviar for two in the front. Despite its somewhat-uptight first impression, this restaurant can become the craziest and funnest place in Paris. Even the waiters end up dancing on tables. When in the Marais, I love going to [Nanashi](http://www.nanashi.fr/#!/). I always have the salmon chirashi and the fresh desserts. Another spot for Japanese food is [Takara](http://isaora.free.fr/). It's the oldest sushi restaurant in Paris (it opened in 1958) and eating there feels like stepping inside a time machine. Finally, there is a small food market with restaurants in the 


[#shop: /shops/548b586d29bcecb31c8d26df]||||||





—it's the perfect pit stop for a nice lunch outdoors."

items.hed: How Travel—and Paris—Inspired Michael Kors's New Shoe Collection
items.dek: Kors's latest capsule shoe collection was designed for easy packing and with “the consummate, stylish jet-setter” in mind.
items.seoTitle: How Travel—and Paris—Inspired Michael Kors's New Shoe Collection
items.seoDescription: Kors's latest capsule shoe collection was designed for easy packing and with “the consummate, stylish jet-setter” in mind.
items.socialTitle: How Travel—and Paris—Inspired Michael Kors's New Shoe Collection
items.socialDescription: Kors's latest capsule shoe collection was designed for easy packing and with “the consummate, stylish jet-setter” in mind.

items.caption: Like a lot of us, Michael Kors has a love affair with Paris. “My first trip to Europe was to Paris when I was 18,” says the designer. “I immediately fell in love with everything from the food to the architecture to the style.” Fittingly, Kors chose to shoot the campaign for his Jet Set 6 collection in the City of Light. Featuring six pairs of travel-ready styles—from pointed-toe ankle boots to sleek and chic snakeskin slip-on sneakers to a pair of strappy gold platform sandals that give you that instant *je ne sais quoi*—the collection comprises an entire vacation’s worth of shoes, and that was entirely intentional. “Our fans are always on the move,” says Kors. “They’re in L.A. one day, New York the next, then London and Paris and Rio de Janeiro in the following month. They don’t have time to pack, so we made it easy.” Easy, chic shoes that go with everything—now all we need is a ticket to Paris. Click through to see (and shop) the collection.
*Michael Michael Kors Woods Leather Ankle Boot ([michaelkors.com](http://www.michaelkors.com/woods-leather-ankle-boot/_/R-US_40F5WOME5L?No=-1&color=0001), $185)*
*Michael Michael Kors Sabrina Leather Platform Pump ([michaelkors.com](http://www.michaelkors.com/sabrina-leather-platform-pump/_/R-US_40F5SBHP1L?No=-1&color=0001), $170)*
*Michael Michael Kors Kyle Embossed-Leather Slip-on Sneaker ([michaelkors.com](http://www.michaelkors.com/kyle-embossed-leather-slip-on-sneaker/_/R-US_43F5KYFP1E?No=-1&color=0121), $130)*
*Michael Michael Kors Ariel Embossed-Leather Platform Sandal ([michaelkors.com](http://www.michaelkors.com/ariel-embossed-leather-platform-sandal/_/R-US_40F5AIHS1M?color=0705), $160)*
*Michael Michael Kors Gretchen Leather Ankle Boot (michaelkors.com, $250)*
*Michael Michael Kors Bryce Two-Tone Leather Boot ([michaelkors.com](http://www.michaelkors.com/bryce-two-tone-leather-boot/_/R-US_40F5BYMB8L?No=-1&color=0091), $295)*

fields.name: Jayna Maleri
fields.shortBio: Jayna Maleri is the digital style editor for Condé Nast Traveler.

items.hed: Everything You Need to Pack for Paris Fashion Week
items.dek: From sleek day-to-night flats to miracle-working dry shampoo, here's everything you need for seven days of shows in the City of Light.

items.caption: No matter how weary one is after back-to-back fashion weeks in New York, London, and Milan, it’s impossible not to enjoy the Parisian shows that follow. The city is beautiful and romantic, the presentations over-the-top and glamorous, and everyone in attendance seems to channel their inner Coco Chanel. So how can you look the part without completely overpacking? Ahead, 11 must-have pieces to see you through.

items.title: A Polished Carry-On
items.caption:
The fashion world waits for nothing, including the chaos of baggage claim. Ensure no time is lost on your busy itinerary by only bringing along the essentials; everything should fit in an overhead bin-friendly bag. Because it’s likely you’ll run into colleagues at the airport, though, be sure to pick a design that won’t drag down your look.

*Clare V. Weekender ([clarev.com](http://www.clarev.com/products/weekender#Navy-Newlook-Brown-Handles-Weekender), $625)*

items.title: A Suede Trench
items.caption:
A staple Parisian silhouette in the fabric of the season, this piece somehow feels of-the-moment and timeless at once. What’s more, it goes with everything—jeans and T-shirt for a quick croissant run; a minidress on the way to a fancy dinner—so you won’t need to have another outerwear option on hand.

*Topshop Premium Suede Trench Coat ([us.topshop.com](http://us.topshop.com/en/tsus/product/real-suede-trench-coat-4455100), $500)*

items.title: A Stacked Heel Slide
items.caption:
A telltale sign of an out-of-towner? Teetering around awkwardly in uncomfortable heels. To channel the effortless chic of local editors, opt for sturdy lifts you can actually walk in, but with special, outfit-making touches. 

*Rachel Comey Dahl Mule ([rachelcomey.com](http://www.rachelcomey.com/womens-store/shoes/mules/dahl-2.html?color=Gold&size=5.5), $414)*

items.title: Flared Trousers
items.caption:
Well before designers dusted off '70s style and deemed it cool again, Left Bank artist and ingenues were owning the look. Make it yours, too, with a pair of legs-for-days corduroy bell-bottoms.

*Giambattista Valli Jumbo-Corduroy Flared Trousers ([matchesfashion.com](http://www.matchesfashion.com/us/products/Giambattista-Valli-Jumbo-corduroy-flared-trousers--1022660#), $850)*

items.title: A Tie-Neck Blouse
items.caption:
The reliability of a classic, the "It" factor of a statement piece, and the no-brainer appeal of a basic, all wrapped in one versatile package. Even better? You won’t need to bother bringing along necklaces.

*Trademark Stripe Tie Shirt ([trade-mark.com](http://www.trade-mark.com/stripe-tie-shirt.html?___store=default), $318)*

items.title: A Ladylike Purse
items.caption:
You’re going for more feminine sophistication than flash factor here; think sleek silhouettes over novelty shapes, deep jewel tones instead of neons, minimalist hardware in place of wild embellishment. You’ll be carrying it all week, so subtlety is really important.

*A.P.C. June Bag, ([apc.fr](http://usonline.apc.fr/women/bags/june-bag-pxaqg-f61093#Bordeaux&16), $530)*

items.title: Lace-Up Flats
items.caption:
If ballet flats are the quintessential footwear of Parisian women, then a lace-up version is a telltale sign she works in fashion. In all black, the style is a easy way to add an insider-y edge to your outfits, like you’re running from a meeting at [Colette](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2015-07-28/concept-stores-worth-planning-your-vacation-around/3) to sitting front row at Chanel.  

*Loeffler Randall Ambra Lace-Up Flat ([clubmonaco.com](http://www.clubmonaco.com/product/index.jsp?productId=69396026&color=1174801), $295)*

items.title: Bold Earrings
items.caption:
Make no mistake, there will come at least big, buzzy party where nothing you packed seems to live up to the high-profile guest list. Rather than order a *croque monsieur*from room service and turn in for the night, rely on these striking tassels to elevate your ensemble; with a bold lip or cat-eye they're statement enough to go simple everywhere else. 

*Eddie Borgo Small Silk Tassel Earrings ([shopbop.com](https://www.shopbop.com/small-silk-tassel-earrings-eddie/vp/v=1/1573085435.htm?folderID=29949&fm=other-viewall&os=false&colorId=35766), $195)*

items.title: A Dressed-Up Watch
items.caption:
Be it a glossy gold finish or micro diamond inlay (or both), you want details that make your timepiece feel more like a luxe bracelet than a practical measure. That said, it should also help you stick to a schedule, so don’t forgot to adjust the hours when you land.

*Michael Kors Darci Gold-Tone And Amber Watch ([michaelkors.com](http://www.michaelkors.com/darci-gold-tone-and-amber-watch/_/R-US_MK3408?No=8&color=0710), $250)*

items.title: A Denim Midi
items.caption:
Keeping in line with Paris's refined take on laid-back dressing, this streamlined jean skirt is casual in an elegant way. Plan on wearing it to your daily appointments with lace-up flats and a watch, then swapping in heels and statement earrings for an evening event.

*Alexa Chung for AG Beat the Cool Denim Midi Skirt, ([avenue32.com](http://www.avenue32.com/us/beat-the-cool-denim-midi-skirt-69401/), $390)*

items.title: Dry Shampoo
items.caption:
Between your hectic schedule and growing exhaustion from over three weeks on the road, there’s bound to be a few mornings you want to skip washing your hair…or even brushing it. Klorane’s dry shampoo (this small travel size is perfect for stashing in your purse) not only lets you opt out of both, but gives you that *je ne sais quoi*that comes with perfectly tousled bedhead.

*Klorane Dry Shampoo with Oat Milk ([sephora.com](http://www.sephora.com/dry-shampoo-with-oat-milk-P395383?icid2=klorane_lp_spotlight_image&skuId=1253913), $9)*

items.socialTitle: Here's What to Pack if You're Traveling to Paris
items.seoTitle: Everything to Wear at Paris Fashion Week

fields.name: Alison Syrett
fields.shortBio: Alison Syrett is a freelance fashion, beauty and lifestyle writer based in Brooklyn, New York.
fields.bio: Although Alison originally moved to NYC to become a children’s book illustrator, she fell in love with journalism after landing an editorship at Lucky magazine. These days she covers fashion, beauty and lifestyle for several outlets—including *Condé Nast Traveler*, *Fashionista.com* and *Teen Vogue*—but still doodles all over her notes. When she’s not working, you can probably find her shopping, running or eating her way through the city.

items.hed: Where New York’s Most Fashionable People Shop
items.dek: *Traveler* contributing editor Sofia Sanchez de Betak spoke to a few of fashion's most in-the-know tastemakers, and these are the vintage boutiques, bookstores, and shops where you’re most likely to spot the NYFW crowd.
items.seoTitle: Where to Shop During New York Fashion Week
items.seoDescription: The vintage boutiques, bookstores, and shops where you’re most likely to spot the New York Fashion Week crowd.
items.socialTitle: 5 Best Places to Shop Like a Fashion Editor in NYC
items.socialDescription: The vintage boutiques, bookstores, and shops where you’re most likely to spot the New York Fashion Week crowd.
items.body:
[#image: /photos/55f04175cdd1761348be05f3]|||
The Line and The Apartment
|||






New York Fashion week kicks off tomorrow, which means this (already chic) city is about to get an extra dose of style. Editors, photographers, designers, bloggers, and street style stars will be seen scurrying from one show to another as quickly as their (improbably high) heels will take them, but even in a packed week of fashion shows, presentations, dinners, parties, and industry events, there’s always time for a little shopping. We asked some of our favorite tastemakers where they shop when they’re in town for the shows, and these are a few of their can’t-miss spots.
 
##The Line and The Apartment
If there’s one thing New York’s fashionable set can agree on, it’s that no visit to New York is complete without a stop at [The Line and The Apartment](https://www.theline.com/apartment/quintessential_apartment) on Greene Street in SoHo. Created by twins Kate and Morgan Wendelborn and stylist Vanessa Traina, stepping into the light-filled space is a great way to leave the city behind, if only for a few moments. “There is no better escape from the streets of New York Fashion Week than The Line and The Apartment,” says Traina. “You can put your feet up for a minute while shopping a beautifully curated selection of fashion and home and beauty goods. You will no doubt walk out with a new fashion week wardrobe of our classic and covetable pieces.” Style star (and *Condé Nast Traveler*contributing editor) Sofia Sanchez de Betak agrees: “It’s the most comfortable place to shop in the city,” she says “It just feels like you’re at home.” 

##De Vera Antiques
For vintage finds and exquisite antique jewelry, head to the well-curated [De Vera Antiques](http://www.deveraobjects.com/) on Crosby Street. “Every object is chosen with an impeccable eye, and you can expect to find ancient Roman glass next to Meiji period kokeishi dolls,” says brand consultant and curator Hikari Yokoyama. “The owner also makes jewelery from antique pieces like Georgian brooches, hand-cut diamonds, and Sardinian coral. Prices can be shocking,” she warns, “but it is still worth a visit. And don’t be shy—ask questions about the objects, you’ll leave with a mini history lesson.” You also might spot designer Isabel Marant, who calls De Vera “My very own cabinet de curiosités.”


[#image: /photos/5417743017e4b1f634ef077f]||||||





##Fivestory
Though much of the action during New York Fashion Week takes place downtown, 


[#shop: /shops/53eae575976f8f2d44d589e5]||||||





, Claire Distenfeld’s multi-floor shopping experience on the Upper East Side, is a guaranteed way to get the fashion-focused to venture above 14th Street. “New York has a wonderful culture of multi-brand stores where you can always discover new things,” says Hikari Yokoyama “Fivestory is one of my favorites.” It’s also tops fashion consultant and street style star Miroslava Duma’s list. “I love how elegant everything is in Fivestory and how Claire is taking chances with young, not-yet-established designers,” says Duma. “Everyone should try to take time during fashion week to pop in this very inspiring store.”


##What Goes Around Comes Around
For anyone looking to hit the throwback jackpot, vintage store [What Goes Around Comes Around](http://www.whatgoesaroundnyc.com/) on West Broadway has the potential for major payoff. The flagship store, which opened in 1993 (and has since spun off locations in Los Angeles, East Hampton, and Kuwait City) is the best place to go to find luxe secondhand goods, from labels like Chanel, Hermes, and Comme des Garcons. “Shopping here is like a treasure hunt,” says System Magazine co-founder Elizabeth von Guttman. And for those even more adventurous shoppers, here’s a tip, courtesy of Hikari Yokoyama: “You can make an appointment to visit their warehouse, and they’ll let you dig through the massive spread of Americana-focused treasures they have there.” 

##The Strand Bookstore
A New York institution, which famously carries “18 miles of books,” 


[#shop: /shops/53eae576976f8f2d44d589e9]||||||





 is a bibliophile's paradise on Broadway that has been selling new, used, and rare books since 1927. It’s also an unlikely spot to recharge between shows. “I love to go there just to relax and look through old books,” says Sofia Sanchez de Betak. And model/stylist Tati Cotilar puts it even more succinctly when she says: “It’s the best bookstore downtown.”


[#image: /photos/53da965ddcd5888e145be629]||||||


----------


[#cnevideo: /cnevideos/55a548317772ff921f95ea38]||||||
